awd_titl_txt: Designing Bright and Fast Fluorophores with Large Stokes' Shifts Based on Superradiant Molecular J-Aggregates
awd_abstract_narration:
With the support of the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program in the NSF division of Chemistry, Professor Moungi G. Bawendi and his team at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology will study and harness fundamental properties of molecular interactions to develop materials that generate efficient bursts of light in short timescales that are on the order of a few hundred picoseconds. Materials that can emit light quickly and efficiently have a wide range of applications, including deep-space optical communication, high-speed smart light-emitting diodes (LEDs), and quantum information technologies. Inspired by the complexity and exquisite efficiency of natural light harvesting systems, the team will explore how the optical properties of molecules can be improved by arranging them in nano- and microscale clusters called J-aggregates. In addition to this research, the team will work to make science more inclusive by providing opportunities to under-represented minorities and women in order to help develop their scientific potential and empower disadvantaged communities. In particular, the team will take part in the MIT ACCESS program that provides classes and research opportunities to students to help bridge the gap in transitioning from undergraduate to graduate school. The team will also utilize complementary programs aimed at K-12 students to convey the excitement of conducting scientific research.

This project aims to gain understanding of fundamental properties that underlie excitonic behavior, stability, and coupling in interacting molecular J-aggregates to develop materials with short lifetimes that are on the order of hundreds of picoseconds and that feature large Stokes shifts and high quantum yields. Traditional fluorophores are used in a variety of fields and have been optimized for high quantum yield, large Stokes shift, and favorable absorption cross-section. However, their application in systems that require a short response time have been limited due to their inherently long lifetimes that are typically in the nanosecond range. Coupled molecular J-aggregates have the potential to fill the need for fast, bright chromophores. The team will investigate how structural changes and environmental effects alter the excitonic behavior of molecular aggregates, and what dynamics play a role in interactions between aggregates. First, the team will study matrix effects and structural changes in nanotubular light harvesting aggregates, as well as the impact of rigidification through encapsulation in a silica shell. Second, the team will investigate origins of non-radiative loss pathways in molecular aggregates and potential ways to mitigate them. Third, the team will look at the coupling between stabilized nanotubular aggregates to understand the key dynamics involved in energy transfer between supramolecular fluorophores. This research has the potential to lead to a fundamental understanding of the properties that limit excitonic behavior and interactions of J-aggregates.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Fluorophores are powerful tools for transforming light energy from one wavelength to another and for producing light on demand. Traditional fluorophores, used in various fields, have been developed to have efficient emission and strong absorption. However, their application in systems requiring a short response time has been limited due to inherent nanosecond emission lifetimes. In contrast, J-aggregates, which are a class of organized self-assembled dye molecules, exhibit significantly faster picosecond lifetimes compared to unaggregated dyes, owing to the coherent delocalization of excitations among the constituent molecules. This speeding up of the emission is called superradiance. We aimed to develop a new class of robust superradiant fluorophores with high brightness and short picosecond lifetimes. Through this award, we synthesized a novel dye that forms highly emissive J-aggregates, we identified non-emissive recombination pathways in two-dimensional J-aggregates, and we introduced silica encapsulation as a technique to enhance the structural stability of J-aggregates while promoting ordered self-assembly. Our results led to the hypothesis that reducing defects in the J-aggregates would lead to higher brightness. Indeed, we hypothesized that even trace amounts of impurity quenchers could significantly impact the brightness of these molecular assemblies. To investigate the deleterious role of impurities as quenchers, we performed a purification step on the monomers before the assembly process and compared the optical properties of the J-aggregates assembled from the purified dye with those assembled from the as-received dye. We found that purifying monomers before self-assembly improved the brightness of two-dimensional J-aggregate sheets by a factor of ~1.5, while demonstrating a fast 174 ps lifetime. We observed that the brightness continued increasing with aging without undergoing any large-scale structural changes. We hypothesized that the J-aggregate undergoes microscopic self-annealing at room temperature over time, which removes impurity quenchers and corrects faulty packing, leading to a more crystalline and defect-free lattice.

The optical properties of J-aggregates are linked to their structural integrity, rendering them highly sensitive to both chemical environments and mechanical stresses. We developed a process to encase individual J-aggregates in silica (glass) to both stabilize and protect them from their environment. Our stabilization strategy has the potential to establish J-aggregates as a new class of stable materials with robust optical properties, enabling a wide variety of fundamental optical studies on superradiance and light harvesting that were previously hindered by stability concerns. Our novel stabilization procedure, combined with our purification step, gave rise to two-dimensional sheet-like J-aggregates encased in silica, with nearly none of the emissive light quenched, while displaying a fast 234 ps emissive lifetime. These silica-encapsulated J-aggregates are resilient, maintaining structural integrity without substantial disintegration even at a 125-fold dilution, which is not possible with un-encapsulated J-aggregates. The ability to extensively dilute J-aggregates is crucial for exploring the science and potential applications of these novel J-aggregates. Our new silica-J-aggregate hybrids achieve the limits of a bright and fast ideal fluorophore while offering enhanced chemical manipulability through silica encapsulation.

We presented our findings in the form of presentations at major scientific meetings and at other universities. The results have been published in 4 refereed publications. Three graduate students were educated primarily from this work. The outcome of our project describes a new class of bright and fast fluorophores that are unique and that have the potential to become new building blocks in a variety of light emission applications. 

 


Last Modified: 09/26/2024
Modified by: Moungi G Bawendi
